definition: big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
word/statement/speech/lyrics/CL:組|组[zu3],個|个[ge4]/a form of lyric poetry, flourishing in the Song dynasty 宋朝|宋朝[Song4 chao2]/CL:首[shou3]

sentences.english: That’s a slightly Utopian overstatement, but there is some truth in it.
sentences.chinese: 这可能有点夸大其词，但还是有道理的。

sentences.english: She would often romance about her bitter experiences.
sentences.chinese: 她总是夸大其词地讲她的痛苦经历。

sentences.english: People will not believe a man who always exaggerates.
sentences.chinese: 人们不会相信老是夸大其词的人。

sentences.english: Do you think I am exaggerating?
sentences.chinese: 你认为我是在夸大其词吗？

sentences.english: False, that is exaggerated, insincere, courteously but without sincerity, cover-up.
sentences.chinese: 假，就是夸大其词，言不由衷，虚与委蛇，文过饰非。

sentences.english: This was exaggerated in the media coverage of AIDS-treatment with Chinese medicine.
sentences.chinese: 这在媒体上被夸大其词地报道成用中药治疗艾滋病。

sentences.english: There was no bombast or conceit in his speech.
sentences.chinese: 他的演讲并没有夸大其词和自吹自擂。

sentences.english: You could receive communications from your employer that feel over-the-top.
sentences.chinese: 你可能会收到你老板的感觉有些夸大其词的留条。

definition: to sensationalize (idiom); deliberate exaggeration to scare people
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
to concoct a cock-and-bull story (idiom)/to make things up
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
